Name: Lower Silesian
Description: Located in southwestern Poland, known for Wrocław, medieval castles, and mountain ranges.

Name: Kuyavian-Pomeranian
Description: A central-northern region with historic cities like Bydgoszcz and Toruń, known for medieval architecture.

Name: Lublin
Description: An eastern region known for its cultural heritage, historic castles, and picturesque landscapes.

Name: Lubusz
Description: A western region with beautiful forests, national parks, and a mix of German-Polish heritage.

Name: Lodz
Description: Located in central Poland, Lodz is an industrial and cultural hub with vibrant arts and film scenes.

Name: Lesser Poland
Description: Home to Kraków, the Tatra Mountains, and UNESCO-listed sites, rich in history and culture.

Name: Masovian
Description: Poland’s largest and most populous region, home to the capital city, Warsaw.

Name: Opole
Description: The smallest Polish voivodeship, known for its multicultural heritage and German influence.

Name: Podkarpackie
Description: Located in southeastern Poland, featuring the Carpathian Mountains and Bieszczady National Park.

Name: Podlaskie
Description: A northeastern region rich in natural beauty, forests, and diverse cultures, including Belarusian influences.

Name: Pomeranian
Description: Home to the Baltic coast, historic Gdańsk, and major seaports.

Name: Silesian
Description: A highly urbanized and industrialized region with Katowice as its center.

Name: Swietokrzyskie
Description: A central-southern region known for its Holy Cross Mountains and historic sites.

Name: Warmian-Masurian
Description: A northeastern region famous for its thousands of lakes and untouched nature.

Name: Greater Poland
Description: The historic heartland of Poland, home to the city of Poznań and many medieval landmarks.

Name: West Pomeranian
Description: A coastal region with major ports, sandy beaches, and historic Szczecin.
